THE MAYORALTY.
Although five candidates were nominated for the position of Chief Magistrate of this town, some of them we understand without any consent have already stated they shall have something to say in another paragraph, it appears to be pretty well settled as polling day approaches that the contest for this honorable position will be narrowed down to two candidates—Mr. Knowles and Mr. Smith. These gentlemen are so well known to the community that it would be useless for us to expatiate on their relative merits.

The one an old pioneer and a leading member of the town, while the other a leading banker and authority on finance and will calculated to bring this important branch of our municipal system upon a sound basis.

With two such men before our citizens, we do not feel called upon to express any definite preference, but prefer to let the language of one of our writers—"best of both"—stand by and see fair play, and leave them both in the hands of our intelligent electorate, who will doubtless select the best man.

Meanwhile we congratulate the town on its good feeling and absence of the usual mud slinging that has so far characterized these elections.

Contrary to expectation the opinion of the Supreme Court at Ottawa on the Manitoba's crossing case has been unanimously against the C. P. R. The point in dispute was as to whether the Manitoba Legislature had power to enact legislation authorizing the Red River Valley railway to enter the province. The decision of the C. P. R., that railway having been declared a work for the general advantage of Canada. The judges of the Supreme Court have decided that the legislature of Manitoba had no power, and that the crown can be made after the Railway Committee of the Privy Council has approved of the mode and place. The general opinion of the Press of Eastern Canada is that the decision is unsatisfactory, as no grounds are given why it should be so. An appeal will most probably be heard by the C. P. R. to the Imperial Privy Council, which will take up some more valuable time. In the meantime the R. R. V. railway will be at a standstill, unless the courts in Manitoba refuse to grant any more injunctions, in which case the road will doubtless be completed as a private enterprise pending their appearance to the Privy Council, use force to prevent a crossing; but such action would, we believe, lead to serious trouble.

There is something wrong in our Municipal Ordinance. Candidates for Mayor or Councillor should be compelled to make a deposit at their nomination. The candidate should be required to give his name to the nominating committee in writing or his backers should make a declaration that he has or will consent to the nomination, then we would not be liable to have so many men nominated who have no intention of running, as was the case at the last election. Against this proposal an elector in a ward should be allowed to nominate candidates for that ward. Here we have every year men nominated without their knowledge or consent by parties who, with a reckless disregard for the welfare of the town, put themselves through the trouble and annoyance, they put others to, doing it for fun." When the interests at stake of the town are at stake strict conduct should be severely condemned and provision made in the law whereby it would be guarded against.

The Regina Leader makes serious charges against the Committee of the N. W. M. P. I sympathize with the Regina members in the cantent matter, and hope that they will take such action as will result in the breaking up of what is apparently a job on a large scale and which may be extended to other parts of the Territories.

COMMUNICATIONS.
It must be distinctly understood that we do not agree with the opinions expressed by correspondents in our columns, nor do we agree in full, nor necessarily for publication in any form, with the views expressed by any contributor.

QUEBEC'S SPEECH.
To the Editor of the Times.
Sir,—With regard to your report of the speech delivered by Hon. Sir George-Étienne Cartier at the opening of the National Academy, while I agree with that affection is repugnant to Northerners, allow me to state that there is nothing in his speech that is repugnant, and that is an unmitigated reflection on the nationality and religion of a considerable portion of our population. I trust that your paper will not be unkind or hurt the feelings of anybody in your paper, will be carried out in alleged semi-religious entertainments.

Yours truly,

TERRITORIAL NEWS

LETHBRIDGE.

From the News, Dec. 18.

His Lordship the Bishop of Lethbridge has been obliged to arrive here on Wednesday morning in order to attend the services in the church. He will be present at the morning service this morning, and on behalf of the congregation, present his wishes for the prosperity of the city.

To the Right Rev. His Lordship of Saint John's and Calgary—The petition of the undersigned residents attending the Anglican Church, Lethbridge, respectfully asks:

That the Rev. J.F. Prichard, who has been the parish priest for six months, be given the opportunity to continue his duties in such a manner as to secure for himself the confidence and favour of the congregation.

That as the result of his labours the congregation has grown in numbers and increased in regularity of worship, he be encouraged to continue his labours in the diocese, whereby the position of the church has been greatly improved.

That in view of the above, they pray that Your Lordship may please be so good as to recommend the Rev. Mr. Prichard to the permanent incumbency of St. Andrew's Church, Calgary, and that your petitioners will ever pray.

His Lordship in reply said it gave him great pleasure to hear the prayers of his flock, and he would be pleased to grant the request of the congregation, and would, during the year, indeed the Rev. Mr. Prichard into the incumbency.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald, Dec. 15.

Eggs scarce at 60c. to 75c. per dozen.

The ladies of Battleford have issued invitations to a leap year ball, to be given on New Year's Eve.

The public will be very highly pleased to learn that Battleford Post Office has at last been made a money order office.

The new post office will go into operation about the new year.

Neither snow nor cold weather have prevented more than two weeks' rain in Battleford.

One day's work was done by the men going out without hindrance, and cattle that are on the range were come back under care being brought in, partly as a natural result, partly to the credit of the season of 1879 and 1877 were in every respect similar to the present.

CALGARY.

From the Tribune, Dec. 19.

Yesterday evening Bishop Hughson visited Wainwright, who has been employed on Simson's ranches for the last three years, was brought to town on account of being ill.

A small snow slide occurred about four miles on this side of Field yesterday. The slide was about seventy-five feet long and from thirty-five to forty feet wide. Two teams were sent out from Lagass, Field and the track cleared in a short time. The train from Field was being delayed by the couple of hours.

On Saturday Capt. Jackson, who lives about two miles out, drove into town with a couple of pigs in his wagon, an extraordinary sight in this part of the country. They consisted of a couple of young boars, one cinnamon and the other black, that were purchased at the last sale of cattle.

The cinnamon one is a lusty chap, weighing about 200 pounds, while the black one is only 125 pounds. Capt. Jackson had the animals down to have them photographed. They are quite tame and gentle and playful about their owner's presence.

This has generally been considered to be a prohibition country; but from the evidence laid before the Assembly it would appear that this is all a mistake. According to the documents adduced to us, there are 35,000 gallons of beer, 40 per cent and 6,000 gallons of liquor into ending June 31st, which is not so bad for a population of about 30,000 white people.

Christmas Tree at St Andrew's

A very successful Christmas Tree entertainment was given by St. Andrew's school at their annual Christmas tree. The proceedings commenced with recitations and singing by the children, who performed in a manner extremely well conducted. Santa Claus then appeared on the scene, in the person of Mr. Andrew Spencer, who was well liked, and distributed his gifts of presents to the delighted children, and to others also, among whom the widows of the parish were included. After the close, Mr. Macdonald J. McKay gave a short address, and then proceeded on the platform, where he addressed the platform and the young folks spent the rest of the evening in their favorite occupation.

A substantial supper was also provided to which the large number of guests and people present were invited. Several visitors shared the pleasure of a very enjoyable evening, and left behind many delightful memories of a few hours that will be cherished by all.

The proceedings were most successfully carried out, and credit is due to the promoters and managers of the entertainment. The people of St. Andrew's have, from the first, shown, under the guidance of a few public-spirited individuals, a praiseworthy and enlightened interest in the education of the young. Ever before the advent of the present principal, the school entertainments were within their reach, they had ignored the services of an educated teacher, Mr. Bernard, under whose management the school has reached a high state of efficiency.
